div1.p: Moran makes arrangements to meet Hench in Havana.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, March 31, 1940
div1.opener:
COMPAÑIA SUNOCO DE CUBA, S.A.
SUBSIDIARIA DE
SUN OIL COMPANY
SUN OILS
“SUNOCO”
CABLE Y}
TELEGRAFO}
CLAVE BENTLEY
TELEFONO U-6148
SUNOCO
DESTILADO AL MERCURIO
VIA AIR MAIL
AVENIDA MENOCAL NOS. 455-457
HABANA.
March 31, 1940.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
c/o Villa Atlantique,
Atlantic Avenue,
Palm Beach, Florida.
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Every since I received your letter dated March 12th,
I have been in a quandary as to whether or not I could assure you
that I would be in Havana from April 8th to to 12th, inclusive, so as
to do justice to the matter we both have in mind. It all hinges on
the plans for arrival here of a Mining Engineer, whose name I do not
even know, whom I MUST accompany on a visit of inspection of Sun Oil
Company's mining properties in the Province of Oriente. Even my Home
Office cannot inform me as to the expected date of his arrival here,
thus leaving me “up in the air”, so to speak. The Director of our
Foreign Department has been with me during the last week, having left
last night on the Ward Liner “ORIENTE” for New York. You can imagine
that I had a hectic week with him, showing him around, etc., etc.

Everything considered, I think you had better carry
out the plan outlined in your letter, that is to say, to arrive here
on or about April 8th. Come what may, I will hold the Engineer here
in Havana so as to give you the most of two days, instead of spreading
it over three or four days. The only fly in the ointment is that he
might arrive around the fourth of April. In such an event, I would
be with him for eight days at least, perhaps ten. Should he arrive
here on the first of April, chances are we would be back to Havana on
the 9th or 10th, which would allow me sufficient time to spend three
or four days with you without interruption. There will be but little
limit on the time I can devote to you if I do not have to leave Havana.
I am my own boss in Cuba and my office manager can take care of the
business end of it. As soon as the Engineer arrives I will send you
a cable indicative of the date, more or less, of my return to Havana.
Should he arrive here on the same date as you plan to arrive here, I
could hold him up for two days while he looks Havana over. I can find
a number of pretexts for so doing. By all means, I want you to come
on to Havana and will arrange somehow to give you practically two days'
full time, including some time in the evening, if you do not mind.
